A challenge going forward will be to accurately model long-wave velocity modes simultaneously with Illustris-like high resolution to capture the complexities of galaxy formation and its correlations with large scale flows.

L]KS

1. Introduction

The cosmic microwave background (CMB) is a powerful probe of cosmic history through secondary anisotropies generated by free electrons in the intergalactic medium, resulting in a spectral distortion and cluster-concentrated anisotropies from inverse Compton scattering off of hot gas in galaxy clusters, the thermal Sunyaev-Zelâ€™dovich (tSZ) effect (e.g., Sunyaev and Zeldovich, 1972), and spectrally undistorted temperature anisotropies from Thompson scattering from moving electrons participating in the bulk flow of the medium, the kinetic Sunyeav-Zelâ€™dovich (kSZ) (e.g., Sunyaev and Zeldovich, 1980) effect.

Of these two, the tSZ effect is much easier to detect because it is determined by electron pressure, which is much higher in clusters. The distinct spectral signature allows it to be separated from other sky signals if observations are made in multiple frequency bands. Because the tSZ effect is dominated by massive clusters, however, it gives a rather biased view of the intergalactic medium, concentrated towards the rarest peaks at relatively late times, zâ‰²1.5less-than-or-similar-toğ‘§1.5z\lesssim 1.5 (e.g., Komatsu and Seljak, 2002). The kSZ effect, on the other hand, while much more difficult to detect, is affected by all ionized gas regardless of its temperature, providing a more global and unbiased view of the universe during and after reionization. The next generation of ground based CMB surveys, such as the Simons Observatory (SO111http://simonsobservatory.org) and CMB-S4222http://cmb-s4.org (Abazajian etÂ al., 2016) will use the kSZ effect both as a probe of the intergalactic medium (HernÃ¡ndez-Monteagudo etÂ al., 2015; Schaan etÂ al., 2016; Hill etÂ al., 2016; Soergel etÂ al., 2016; De Bernardis etÂ al., 2017; Battaglia etÂ al., 2017): cosmology with large-scale velocity flows (Mueller etÂ al., 2015a; Sugiyama etÂ al., 2017; Mueller etÂ al., 2015b; Alonso etÂ al., 2016) will soon become a reality.

The kSZ effect can be detected in the cosmic microwave background alone or by cross-correlating it with tracers of large-scale structure such as galaxies and clusters. Cross correlation is done by combining CMB temperature maps with line intensity maps in the EOR (Cooray, 2004; Salvaterra etÂ al., 2005; Alvarez etÂ al., 2006), with projected fields of large scale structure (e.g., DorÃ© etÂ al., 2004; Ferraro etÂ al., 2015; Hill etÂ al., 2016), or by stacking on groups and clusters (Schaan etÂ al., 2016; Soergel etÂ al., 2016). These techniques use the fact that the peculiar velocities responsible for the effect are correlated with large scale density fluctuations, while the electron density fluctuations required to avoid line of sight cancellation occur on small scales. This separation of linear velocity modes on large scales and density fluctuation on small scales also greatly simplifies the modeling.

The kSZ effect is quite challenging to detect robustly using CMB temperature measurements alone. On large scales, the power spectrum is subdominant but has the same frequency spectrum as the much stronger primary temperature fluctuations (e.g., Hu and Dodelson, 2002). On smaller scales where it does dominate over the primary, â„“â‰³4000greater-than-or-equivalent-toâ„“4000\ell\gtrsim 4000, it competes with other secondary signals such as the cosmic infrared background and tSZ, made especially difficult because they will be correlated and there are not enough frequency bands to separate the components in spite of their rather different frequency spectra. Experiments are in development that will help to give the resolution, sensitivity and frequency coverage to make for a very promising kSZ future in observations. There have been detections reported in the literature, the best so far from the South Pole Telescope at a multipole moment of â„“âˆ¼3000similar-toâ„“3000\ell\sim 3000: ğ’Ÿâ„“=3000kSZ=2.9Â±1.3â€‹Î¼â€‹K2superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿâ„“3000kSZplus-or-minus2.91.3ğœ‡superscriptğ¾2\mathcal{D}_{\ell=3000}^{\rm kSZ}=2.9\pm 1.3~{}\mu K^{2} (George etÂ al., 2015), where ğ’Ÿâ„“â‰¡â„“â€‹(â„“+1)â€‹Câ„“/2â€‹Ï€subscriptğ’Ÿâ„“â„“â„“1subscriptCâ„“2ğœ‹\mathcal{D}_{\ell}\equiv\ell(\ell+1)\rm{C}_{\ell}/2\pi. However, combining the South Pole Telescope, Atacama Cosmology Telescope and Planck data removes the detection and instead gives an upper bound of ğ’Ÿâ„“=3000kSZ<1.79â€‹Î¼â€‹K2superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿâ„“3000kSZ1.79ğœ‡superscriptğ¾2\mathcal{D}_{\ell=3000}^{\rm kSZ}<1.79~{}\mu K^{2} (Planck Collaboration etÂ al., 2016). In future CMB experiments, the kSZ power spectrum should be unveiled by using independent polarization measurements to predict the primary temperature power spectrum and subtract it, leaving the kSZ (Calabrese etÂ al., 2014). Another approach is beyond the 2-point power spectrum, for example correlating with the square of filtered temperature fluctuations (Smith and Ferraro, 2016).

One of the primary reasons such effort is being made to isolate the kSZ contribution from primary fluctuations is to better understand the epoch of reionization. Gas density and velocity fluctuations during reionization had not yet formed nonlinear structure on galaxy and cluster scales, but the patchiness of the reionization process itself created order unity fluctuations in the electron density, and this is predicted to account for half or more of the total kSZ power. A prerequisite step for studying the EOR kSZ signal is to determine better the post-reionization part and subtract it from the total of the two components. Several attempts have been made to translate the observational kSZ limit into a constraint on the timing and duration of reionization (Zahn etÂ al., 2012; Mesinger etÂ al., 2012; Battaglia etÂ al., 2013), although self-regulation of low-mass galaxies (Park etÂ al., 2013) and the highly uncertain dependence on the mean free path of the percolation phase of reionization (Alvarez and Abel, 2012) creates a degeneracy in that parametrization. How to constrain the epoch of reionization with the kSZ signal is only partly understood and is an active area of investigation.

The late-time temperature power spectrum is also the primary statistic that describes the overall scale dependence of fluctuations in the intergalactic medium, and understanding how it depends on baryonic processes in the post-reionization universe is of fundamental importance.

In this paper, we utilize the Illustris simulation (Nelson etÂ al., 2015; Vogelsberger etÂ al., 2013) as a case study for feedback and associated baryonic effects on electron density fluctuations and hence the kSZ power spectrum. Illustris is a recent cosmological hydrodynamic simulation of structure formation with a reasonably large (75â€‹hâˆ’1â€‹Mpc75superscriptâ„1Mpc75~{}h^{-1}~{}\rm{Mpc}) sample volume, which has the advantage of being publicly available with sufficient resolution to probe the multi-phase gas distribution within galaxies and groups on cosmological scales that includes the important effects determining the distribution of electrons, such as feedback from star formation and AGNs. The dark matter particle number and initial gas mesh number is (1820)3superscript18203(1820)^{3}, sufficient to resolve the small-scale impact on the kSZ effect.

The kSZ signal is a line of sight integral of âˆ’Î³^â‹…ÏƒTâ€‹neâ€‹ğ¯eâ‹…^ğ›¾subscriptğœğ‘‡subscriptğ‘›ğ‘’subscriptğ¯ğ‘’-\hat{\gamma}\cdot\sigma_{T}n_{e}\mathbf{v}_{e}, where nesubscriptğ‘›ğ‘’n_{e} is the electron density, ğ¯esubscriptğ¯ğ‘’\mathbf{v}_{e} its peculiar velocity, âˆ’Î³^^ğ›¾-\hat{\gamma} is the photon direction (towards us), and ÏƒTsubscriptğœğ‘‡\sigma_{T} is the Thompson cross section. In addition to using Illustris to better understand how electron density fluctuations evolve over time and are biased with respect to the dark matter, we also investigate the contribution of the 4-point connected component on the power spectrum, a decidedly nonlinear effect. The current neâ€‹ğ¯esubscriptğ‘›ğ‘’subscriptğ¯ğ‘’n_{e}\mathbf{v}_{e} can be decomposed into the gradient of a potential and the curl of a vector. In Fourier space, the gradient term is along the direction of the wavenumber, whereas the curl piece is perpendicular to it. The gradient component gives the linear components from recombination familiar from primary CMB anisotropies, but the kSZ power spectrum is primarily sourced by fluctuations in the curl component, ğªâŸ‚=[ğ¯eâ€‹(1+Î´e)]âŸ‚subscriptğªperpendicular-tosubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ¯ğ‘’1subscriptğ›¿ğ‘’perpendicular-to\mathbf{q_{\perp}}=[\mathbf{v}_{e}(1+\delta_{e})]_{\perp}. For full ionization, this is the transverse momentum field of the gas. The vorticity of the gas becomes nonzero when shocks occur, but is sub-dominant in its influence. Since our focus here is on the kSZ power spectrum, we want to study the power spectrum of ğªâŸ‚=[ğ¯eâ€‹Î´e]âŸ‚subscriptğªperpendicular-tosubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ¯ğ‘’subscriptğ›¿ğ‘’perpendicular-to\mathbf{q_{\perp}}=[\mathbf{v}_{e}\delta_{e}]_{\perp} in order to model the signal. Schematically this power spectrum is a four-point function of two densities and velocities, which can be decomposed into an unconnected part, involving the sum of products of two-point functions and a connected 4-point function, âŸ¨Î´â€‹vâ€‹Î´â€‹vâŸ©csubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ›¿ğ‘£ğ›¿ğ‘£ğ‘\left<\delta v\delta v\right>_{c}: âŸ¨qâ€‹qâŸ©=âŸ¨Î´â€‹Î´âŸ©â€‹âŸ¨vâ€‹vâŸ©+2â€‹âŸ¨Î´â€‹vâŸ©2+âŸ¨Î´â€‹vâ€‹Î´â€‹vâŸ©cdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ›¿ğ›¿delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘£ğ‘£2superscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ›¿ğ‘£2subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ›¿ğ‘£ğ›¿ğ‘£ğ‘\left<qq\right>=\left<\delta\delta\right>\left<vv\right>+2\left<\delta v\right>^{2}+\left<\delta v\delta v\right>_{c}. The connected term arises when the density or velocity field becomes non-Gaussian.

Early analytic work focused on the linear regime calculation in which the density and velocity fields are Gaussian-distributed and the connected term does not exist (Ostriker and Vishniac, 1986; Vishniac, 1987; Dodelson and Jubas, 1995; Jaffe and Kamionkowski, 1998). Later, calculations for the nonlinear density field were done by replacing the linear density power spectrum in the expression for the unconnected part, but the connected term was ignored (Hu, 2000; Ma and Fry, 2002; Zhang etÂ al., 2004; Shaw etÂ al., 2012). Recently, a few studies reported that the connected term can add a significant amount of power in the cases where the density field becomes highly non-Gaussian. Park etÂ al. (2016)(hereafter P16) showed that nonlinear growth of structure can introduce âˆ¼30%similar-toabsentpercent30\sim 30\% extra momentum power at kâˆ¼1â€‹Mpcâˆ’1similar-toğ‘˜1superscriptMpc1k\sim 1~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}, leading to âˆ¼10%similar-toabsentpercent10\sim 10\% more post-reionization kSZ signal. For incomplete ionization during the reionization epoch, the ionization fraction is also associated with correlated processes distinct from the gas density, which should be described as a 6-point function and is almost impossible to estimate except through simulation. Alvarez (2016) measured a âˆ¼30%similar-toabsentpercent30\sim 30\% excess kSZ signal from the patchy ionized density field in their epoch of reionization simulation. It is reasonable to expect the baryonic physics would add to the non-Gaussianity in the plasma density field. We aim to confirm that hypothesis in this work. Maps made of the kSZ effect with concentrated regions of electron density in groups and clusters and with velocities self-consistently included have for a long time included aspects of the nonzero connected 4-point pieces.

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we express the kSZ signal in terms of transverse momentum power spectrum and describe how the unconnected terms of transverse momentum power spectrum are related to the density and velocity power spectra. In Section 3, we describe the Illustris simulation, which we will mainly use for our analyses. In Section 4, we quantify how the baryonic physics affect the plasma density power spectra, and contrast it with the momentum power for dark matter. We then measure the contribution of the connected term in the transverse momentum power spectrum from the simulation. We also report the post-reionization kSZ signal from the simulation along with values reported by other recent works. In section 5, we summarize and discuss our results.

We characterize how the electron density power PÎ´â€‹Î´esubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{e}_{\delta\delta} differs from the dark matter power PÎ´â€‹Î´dsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{d}_{\delta\delta} by a scale and redshift dependent bias, defined here by

To see the combined effects in both fesubscriptğ‘“ğ‘’f_{e} and PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}}, Shaw etÂ al. (2012) (hereafter SRN12) introduced a window function,

which we adopt in this work to describe the baryonic effects.

We note that PqâŸ‚,uâ€‹csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¢ğ‘P_{q_{\perp},uc} does not fully account for PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} in the nonlinear regime due to the rise of the connected term, PqâŸ‚,csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘P_{q_{\perp},c}. P16 confirmed that it is present and important to include for the pure dark matter momentum field. We find the connected term is still important for the electrons, but differs in detail because of the relative bias.

3. Simulation

For our analysis of the power, and its deconstruction into connected and unconnected parts, we use the publicly available results from Illustris, a hydrodynamic simulation of galaxy formation from cosmological initial conditions in a (75â€‹hâˆ’1â€‹Mpc)3superscript75superscriptâ„1Mpc3(75~{}h^{-1}~{}\rm{Mpc})^{3} comoving volume periodic box. Its hydrodynamics and gravitational dynamics are driven by the moving mesh code, AREPO (Springel, 2010). It uses sub-grid prescriptions for chemical cooling of the gas, subsequent star and black-hole formation, and the feedback of stars and black-holes on the surrounding medium. The details of the sub-grid models are described in Vogelsberger etÂ al. (2013) and Torrey etÂ al. (2014). The simulation starts with 18203superscript182031820^{3} dark matter particles, each having 6.26Ã—106â€‹MâŠ™6.26superscript106subscriptğ‘€direct-product6.26\times 10^{6}~{}M_{\odot}. The number of resolution elements for the gas is the same, with the initial mass of 1.26Ã—106â€‹MâŠ™1.26superscript106subscriptğ‘€direct-product1.26\times 10^{6}~{}M_{\odot}. This setup allows halos to be resolved down to 108â€‹Mâ˜‰superscript108subscriptğ‘€â˜‰10^{8}~{}M_{\sun} in mass, and power spectra to be reliable up to kâˆ¼10â€‹hâ€‹Mpcâˆ’1similar-toğ‘˜10â„superscriptMpc1k\sim 10~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} in wavenumber. The cosmology is based on a tilted Î›Î›\LambdaCDM model with Î©m=0.2726subscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.2726\Omega_{m}=0.2726, h=0.704â„0.704h=0.704, Î©b=0.0456subscriptÎ©ğ‘0.0456\Omega_{b}=0.0456, Ïƒ8=0.809subscriptğœ80.809\sigma_{8}=0.809, and ns=0.963subscriptğ‘›ğ‘ 0.963n_{s}=0.963.

Illustris aims to provide a realistic sample of the universe by matching galactic properties with observation. Halos in Illustris are identified by a standard friends-of-friends (FoF) algorithm with linking length b=0.2ğ‘0.2b=0.2. Then the SUBFIND algorithm of Springel etÂ al. (2001) is used to identify subhalos, which are regarded as galaxies. Illustris is known to reproduce the stellar mass function and the luminosity function of galaxies reasonably well and results in a realistic morphological composition of galaxies. The key results from Illustris on galactic properties are discussed in Vogelsberger etÂ al. (2014) and Genel etÂ al. (2014).

The snapshots of Illustris are readily available on the web. We use particle snapshots for z=0,0.5,1,2,3,4,ğ‘§00.51234z=0,0.5,1,2,3,4, and 555 in this work. The snapshots contains masses, locations and velocities of dark and gas particles, and free electron fractions, required for computing the transverse momentum power spectra of the species present.

4. Results

4.1. Density Power Spectrum of Dark Matter and Free Electron

We show the power spectra of dark matter (PÎ´â€‹Î´dsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{d}_{\delta\delta}) and free electron (PÎ´â€‹Î´esubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{e}_{\delta\delta}) density fields in the right panels of FigureÂ 1 for z=0,1,3,ğ‘§013z=0,~{}1,~{}3, and 5. Nonlinearity results in the familiar result of PÎ´â€‹Î´dsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{d}_{\delta\delta} growing faster than the linear theory prediction. At k>1â€‹hâ€‹Mpcâˆ’1ğ‘˜1â„superscriptMpc1k>1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}, PÎ´â€‹Î´dsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{d}_{\delta\delta} is about an order of magnitude larger than the linear prediction at z=0ğ‘§0z=0. As is well known from previous works, the HALOFIT model of Smith etÂ al. (2003) does a good job in modeling this enhancement. The evolution of PÎ´â€‹Î´esubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{e}_{\delta\delta}, however, is more complicated, showing the effects of dynamical nonlinear growth at zâ‰¥3ğ‘§3z\geq 3, but complicated by separation of gas from baryons by shocking and feedback, combining to give a growth slower than linear after z=3ğ‘§3z=3. How this difference between PÎ´â€‹Î´dsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{d}_{\delta\delta} and PÎ´â€‹Î´esubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{e}_{\delta\delta} arises due to the effects of baryonic physics of plasma is what we aim to probe.

A list of relevant baryonic physics that will impact the free electrons relative to the dark matter are:

  • 1)

    Collapse of cooled gas

  • 2)

    Star-formation converting gas into stars and blackholes

  • 3)

    AGN feedback blowing gas out of potential wells

  • 4)

    Self-shielding of cold neutral gas in galaxies against ionizing radiation

  • 5)

    He II reionization at zâˆ¼3similar-toğ‘§3z\sim 3

For example, the density map of free electron in comparison to that of dark matter (See the left panels of FigureÂ 1) shows the smoothing of the electron density field at ğ’›â‰¤ğŸğ’›1\bm{z\leq 1} at certain scales that we can attribute to the effect of AGN feedback. The spread extends over larger scales than in some other gasdynamical calculations, a consequence of the strong feedback in Illustris. This explains the deficit in PÎ´â€‹Î´esubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{e}_{\delta\delta} compared to PÎ´â€‹Î´dsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{d}_{\delta\delta} at high kğ‘˜k and low redshift. To further analyze the differences, we now explore the window function Wesubscriptğ‘Šğ‘’W_{e} (Eq.Â 11).

4.2. Window Functions of Baryon, Gas, and Free Electrons

The window function for the free electrons relative to dark matter Wesubscriptğ‘Šğ‘’W_{e} encodes the effect of all of the baryonic physics relevant to the intergalactic plasma. To help deconstruct its shape we explore equivalent window functions for baryons (Wbsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘W_{b}) and gas (Wgsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘”W_{g}) as well, defined similarly to Wesubscriptğ‘Šğ‘’W_{e}, except that we use baryon and gas densities are used instead of electron number density in EquationÂ (2). The baryon density field includes all the mass in stars, AGNs and neutral gas as well as gas and we can thus use it to exclude the effect of converting gas into those elements that do not give rise to the kSZ effect. The gas density field does include neutral gas in galaxies, but not stars or AGNs, which allows us to decompose the effect of having multiphase gas. We show Wb,Wg,subscriptğ‘Šğ‘subscriptğ‘Šğ‘”W_{b},~{}W_{g}, and Wesubscriptğ‘Šğ‘’W_{e} in FigureÂ 3 for z=0,0.5,1,2,ğ‘§00.512z=0,~{}0.5,~{}1,~{}2, and 4.

In Wbsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘W_{b} an up-turn appears at kâˆ¼5â€‹hâ€‹Mpcâˆ’1similar-toğ‘˜5â„superscriptMpc1k\sim 5~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} at all redshifts shown, a trend easily understood by the collapse of gas on small scales following gas cooling in over-dense regions. At zâ‰¤2ğ‘§2z\leq 2, the feedback of star-formation and AGNs heats the gas and makes it expand over time, damping Wbsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘W_{b} at kâ‰³0.3â€‹hâ€‹Mpcâˆ’1greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘˜0.3â„superscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 0.3~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}. The combination of these two effects creates a dipper-like shape in Wb2superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘2W_{b}^{2} at zâ‰¤1ğ‘§1z\leq 1.

The comparison of Wgsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘”W_{g} to Wbsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘W_{b} demonstrates the effect of star-formation. As gas is converted into stars in density peaks, gas density power is strongly suppressed at kâ‰³1â€‹hâ€‹Mpcâˆ’1greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘˜1â„superscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}. As a result, the up-turn at high-kğ‘˜k is much weaker in Wgsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘”W_{g}. Additionally, star-formation suppresses Wgsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘”W_{g} at all wavenumbers as can be seen from the low-kğ‘˜k limit of Wg2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Š2ğ‘”W^{2}_{g} being less than one. For the case in which a fraction (1âˆ’fg)1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘”(1-f_{g}) of gas was of converted into stars homogeneously, Wg2superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘”2W_{g}^{2} would be suppressed by a factor of fg2superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘”2f_{g}^{2}. In Illustris we find Wg2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Š2ğ‘”W^{2}_{g} drops below fg2superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘”2f_{g}^{2} at low kğ‘˜k because star-formation drains gas preferentially in over-densities and create an anti-bias in the gas density field. The bias of the gas density bgsubscriptğ‘ğ‘”b_{g} shown in the middle right panel of FigureÂ 3 clearly shows this anti-biasing effect in its low-kğ‘˜k limit. To extract the anti-bias, we define bgâ€‹0subscriptğ‘ğ‘”0b_{g0} as Wgâ€‹(kâ†’0)subscriptğ‘Šğ‘”â†’ğ‘˜0W_{g}(k\rightarrow 0). In FigureÂ 4 we plot bgâ€‹02subscriptsuperscriptğ‘2ğ‘”0b^{2}_{g0}, fg2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“2ğ‘”f^{2}_{g}, fg2â€‹bgâ€‹02subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“2ğ‘”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘2ğ‘”0f^{2}_{g}b^{2}_{g0} and their counterparts for electron density. Due to ongoing star-formation, fg2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“2ğ‘”f^{2}_{g} monotonically decreases from 0.92 to 0.8 between z=5ğ‘§5z=5 and 00. bg2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘”2b_{g}^{2} starts from 0.96 at z=0ğ‘§0z=0 and decreases until z=1ğ‘§1z=1 down to 0.92 and stays without much change until z=0ğ‘§0z=0. The combination of these two term, fg2â€‹bgâ€‹02subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“2ğ‘”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘2ğ‘”0f^{2}_{g}b^{2}_{g0}, gives a large-scale suppression effect that grows from 5%percent55\% to 20%percent2020\% between z=5ğ‘§5z=5 and 00.

Wesubscriptğ‘Šğ‘’W_{e} has additional suppression effects on top of what it inherits from Wgsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘”W_{g} because not all electrons that survived star-formation contribute to the mean ionized plasma: a significant fraction of them are trapped in the cold neutral gas in galaxies that remains self-shielded from extragalactic ionizing radiation or are locked in helium atoms at zâ‰³3greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘§3z\gtrsim 3 where most heliums are only singly ionized even when hydrogen is ionized. Similarly to the comparison of Wgsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘”W_{g} to Wbsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘W_{b}, Wesubscriptğ‘Šğ‘’W_{e} gets an all-wavenumber suppression plus more high-kğ‘˜k suppression compared to Wgsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘”W_{g}, which makes We<Wgsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘’subscriptğ‘Šğ‘”W_{e}<W_{g} at all scales. The filled circles on the curves for Wesubscriptğ‘Šğ‘’W_{e} denote the wavenumber that contributes mostly to the â„“=3000â„“3000\ell=3000 signal at give zğ‘§z, â„“/sâ€‹(z)â„“ğ‘ ğ‘§\ell/s(z). 4.3. Susceptibilities of Gas and Free Electron to Dark Matter: Response Functions compared to Window Functions

However there is a â€œlinear responseâ€ limit in which, e.g.,

The (suitably normalized) susceptibility of nesubscriptğ‘›ğ‘’n_{e} to ÏdsubscriptğœŒğ‘‘\rho_{d} is Ï‡eâ€‹dsubscriptğœ’ğ‘’ğ‘‘\chi_{ed}, with units of inverse volume; the name is chosen because there is a clear relation to the familiar susceptibilities that relate electric and magnetic polarizabilities to applied electromagnetic fields, ultimately leading to dielectric tensors. Another terminology for Ï‡eâ€‹dsubscriptğœ’ğ‘’ğ‘‘\chi_{ed} is response function, for obvious reasons.

In the halo model expansion for the dark matter density, there are susceptibilities for each class of halo, giving the response of Î´dsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘‘\delta_{d} to Mhâ€‹nhsubscriptğ‘€â„subscriptğ‘›â„M_{h}n_{h}, where Mhsubscriptğ‘€â„M_{h} is the halo mass and nhsubscriptğ‘›â„n_{h} the halo number density for that class. In that case, the susceptibilities give the (suitably normalized) mean dark matter profile of the halo class. Usually scalings are done to take out the dominant dependences on the overall size of the halo (or equivalently the overall mass). Thus these ideas are familiar. The Fourier transform Ï‡~eâ€‹hâ€‹(k)subscript~ğœ’ğ‘’â„ğ‘˜\tilde{\chi}_{eh}(k) is the electron density form factor of the halo.

We can relate these ideas to what is done in practice to make mock maps of the kSZ effect, e.g., in the peak patch approach for creating deep all-sky halo catalogs Bond (1996), Bond and Myers (1996), and Alvarez etÂ al. (2017), with analytic or measured susceptibilities used to â€paint onâ€ the electron density profiles around halos. The velocities for the halos are automatic outputs in the peak patch catalog, suitably smoothed over the cluster scale, which changes from cluster to cluster. In Alvarez etÂ al. (2017) the susceptibilities are determined by measurement in the BBPS cosmic hydro simulations of Battaglia etÂ al. (2012), constructing stacked profiles for halos with specified mass and redshift bins, each bin defining a halo-class. The product of the electron density profile and the velocity allows for all-sky mocks of the kSZ effect. The accuracy of the mock then depends upon the magnitude of the residual fluctuations about the mean-field linear-response expansion inherent in this â€œhalo modelâ€ for nesubscriptğ‘›ğ‘’n_{e}.

The Illustris simulations could also be used to calculate the electron density response for each of the halo bins, and be incorporated into the peak-patch simulator in the same way as the BBPS calculations have been. The resolution of Illustris was much superior to BBPS, which has allowed us to study here the influence of galactic-scale baryonic physics that are not resolved in the BBPS simulations, although star and AGN feedback were incorporated. On the other hand, the Illustris box was smaller, and only one box was run, limiting statistical inferences. Thus in Illustris the rare-mass clusters are fewer, exacerbated because there was only one realization. (BBPS ran a (small) ensemble of simulations.) While we await more and larger Illustris and other high resolution simulations for susceptibility measurements, we shall content ourselves here with Ï‡eâ€‹dsubscriptğœ’ğ‘’ğ‘‘\chi_{ed} measurements, estimated by cross-correlations weighted by the inverse of the self-clustering correlation matrix for dark matter <Î´eâ€‹Î´d>â€‹<Î´dâ€‹Î´d>âˆ’1expectationsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘’subscriptğ›¿ğ‘‘superscriptexpectationsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¿ğ‘‘1<\delta_{e}\delta_{d}><\delta_{d}\delta_{d}>^{-1}:

For halos Ï‡~dâ€‹hâ€‹(k)subscript~ğœ’ğ‘‘â„ğ‘˜\tilde{\chi}_{dh}(k) approaches a mass-weighted anti-bias bdâ€‹hâ€‹0subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘â„0b_{dh0} for the halo-class in question at low kğ‘˜k, Î´dâˆ¼Î´h/bhâ€‹dâ€‹0similar-tosubscriptğ›¿ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¿â„subscriptğ‘â„ğ‘‘0\delta_{d}\sim\delta_{h}/b_{hd0}, with bhâ€‹dâ€‹0=Ï‡~hâ€‹dâ€‹(kâ†’0)subscriptğ‘â„ğ‘‘0subscript~ğœ’â„ğ‘‘â†’ğ‘˜0b_{hd0}=\tilde{\chi}_{hd}(k\rightarrow 0) the usual mass-halo dependent bias of halos relative to dark matter density, with bhâ€‹dâ€‹0>1subscriptğ‘â„ğ‘‘01b_{hd0}>1. 4.4. Connected Term in Free Electron Transverse Momentum Power Spectrum

PqâŸ‚,uâ€‹csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¢ğ‘P_{q_{\perp},uc} (Eq.Â 9) was often assumed to represent the complete PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} in previous literature. SRN12 and Zhang etÂ al. (2004) showed that evaluating EquationÂ (9) using density power spectrum from simulations and directly computing PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} gave nearly similar results. P16 recently revisited that comparison with a pure dark matter simulation and found that PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} can be larger than PqâŸ‚,uâ€‹csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¢ğ‘P_{q_{\perp},uc} up to âˆ¼30%similar-toabsentpercent30\sim 30\% at kâ‰³1â€‹hâ€‹Mpcâˆ’1greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘˜1â„superscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} due to the connected term in PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} arising in the nonlinear regime. We shall check on this issue for the free electron momentum field here.

To measure PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} directly from Illustris, we first assign the velocity-weighted electron number of each particle to a nearest grid in a 5123superscript5123512^{3} mesh. Taking the power spectrum of this mesh would however underestimate PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} because it misses velocity modes larger than the size of the simulation box (75â€‹hâˆ’1â€‹Mpc75superscriptâ„1Mpc75~{}h^{-1}~{}\rm{Mpc}) and we thus need to correct for the missing velocity modes not included in the box. We describe how we estimate the correction for those missing modes in the Appendix and show the expression in EquationÂ (A1). In the rest of the paper, we shall use the missing-power-correction-added power spectrum in the analysis and denote it as PqâŸ‚,tâ€‹oâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡P_{q_{\perp},tot}.

In FigureÂ 6, we plot the ratio of PqâŸ‚,tâ€‹oâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡P_{q_{\perp},tot}, and the unconnected part of the spectrum, PqâŸ‚,uâ€‹csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¢ğ‘P_{q_{\perp},uc}, to see if PqâŸ‚,uâ€‹csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¢ğ‘P_{q_{\perp},uc} can fully explains the spectrum. PqâŸ‚,uâ€‹csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¢ğ‘P_{q_{\perp},uc} is calculated by evaluating EquationÂ (9) with the density and velocity power spectra of Illustris. We focus on the higher k>0.5â€‹hâ€‹Mpcâˆ’1ğ‘˜0.5â„superscriptMpc1k>0.5~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} wavenumbers where the kSZ signal is quite relevant and the number of plane-waves in the simulation box are sufficient for good statistically sampling.

At z=47ğ‘§47z=47 where the dark matter density and velocity fluctuations are in the linear regime, PqâŸ‚,tâ€‹oâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡P_{q_{\perp},tot} agrees with PqâŸ‚,uâ€‹csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¢ğ‘P_{q_{\perp},uc} within a percent. At zâ‰¤4ğ‘§4z\leq 4, PqâŸ‚,tâ€‹oâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡P_{q_{\perp},tot} shows some excess power at kâ‰³1â€‹hâ€‹Mpcâˆ’1greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘˜1â„superscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}. The excess grows monotonically toward low-zğ‘§z. At zâ‰¤1ğ‘§1z\leq 1, the growth of the excess power is much faster for the free electron case than in the dark matter case, which we attribute to the baryonic physics adding more non-Gaussianity to the free electron density field. We interpret this excess power,

PqâŸ‚,câ‰¡PqâŸ‚,tâ€‹oâ€‹tâˆ’PqâŸ‚,uâ€‹c,subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¢ğ‘\displaystyle P_{q_{\perp},c}\equiv P_{q_{\perp},tot}-P_{q_{\perp},uc}, (14)

as the contribution from the connected term. We note that this is only a conservative lower-bound since we have made no missing power correction for PqâŸ‚,csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘P_{q_{\perp},c}. If we allow for the same fraction of missing power as in PqâŸ‚,uâ€‹csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘¢ğ‘P_{q_{\perp},uc}, the estimated PqâŸ‚,csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘P_{q_{\perp},c} would nearly double, but the way the waves enter into the 4-point function precludes that being an accurate correction. We discuss how much PqâŸ‚,csubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toğ‘P_{q_{\perp},c} adds to the integrated kSZ signal in the next section.

5. Summary and Discussion

The transverse momentum power spectrum PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} that sources the kSZ signal in the CMB anisotropy has often been computed by substituting the free electron density power spectrum PÎ´â€‹Î´esubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ›¿ğ›¿P^{e}_{\delta\delta} acquired from simulation into EquationÂ (9). According to the equation, PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} at a given wavenumber depends sensitively on PÎ´â€‹Î´subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¿ğ›¿P_{\delta\delta} at similar wavenumbers. Free electron density fluctuations at z<6ğ‘§6z<6 are heavily affected by nonlinear growth of structure and baryonic physics and modeling these nonlinear effects well are the key to estimating accurately the kSZ signal in the post-reionization regime. While nonlinear growth is known to be well described by the HALOFIT model, the baryonic effects are less understood due to the difficulty in implementing the physics into simulation, and are not simply amenable to semi-analytic treatments.

Although not perfectly accurate, Illustris provides a sample distribution of free electron at a high enough resolution in a large enough volume with relevant baryonic physics. Even after the end of reionization, a certain fraction of electron is locked in stars, black-holes, neutral gas, and helium. Since these are located preferentially in over-dense regions, the free electron density fluctuations are suppressed by the anti-bias as well as by the neutral fraction. Another important effect is the feedback from AGNs blowing gas out of groups and clusters, resulting in a strong extra suppression on small scales.

Since the dark matter density field is minimally affected by the baryonic effects, the window function We2=fe2â€‹[PÎ´â€‹Î´e/PÎ´â€‹Î´d]subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Š2ğ‘’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“2ğ‘’delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ›¿ğ›¿subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ›¿ğ›¿W^{2}_{e}=f^{2}_{e}[P^{e}_{\delta\delta}/P^{d}_{\delta\delta}] well separates the baryonic suppression effects on the kSZ signal. According to the window function from the Illustris simulation, the loss of gas and anti-bias suppresses the signal by âˆ¼30%similar-toabsentpercent30\sim 30\% at all scales. Then the extra small-scale suppression by AGN feedback further reduces the signal at kâ‰³1â€‹hâ€‹Mpcâˆ’1greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘˜1â„superscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} at zâ‰²1less-than-or-similar-toğ‘§1z\lesssim 1. This small-scale suppression is more effective for higher â„“â„“\ell. The net suppression in the integrated post-reionization kSZ signal ğ’Ÿâ„“kSZ,z<6subscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸkSZğ‘§6â„“\mathcal{D}^{{\rm kSZ},z<6}_{\ell} is at 50âˆ’60%50percent6050-60\% level at â„“=3000âˆ’10000â„“300010000\ell=3000-10000. We note that this small-scale suppression effect by AGN is likely over-estimated in Illustris. According Genel etÂ al. (2014), Illustris significantly undershoots the gas fraction in halos with Mâ‰³1013â€‹MâŠ™greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘€superscript1013subscriptğ‘€direct-productM\gtrsim 10^{13}M_{\odot} at zâ‰²1less-than-or-similar-toğ‘§1z\lesssim 1 due to exaggeration in the AGN feedback prescription and these halos are an important contributor to the density power spectrum at kâ‰³1â€‹hâ€‹Mpcâˆ’1greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘˜1â„superscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}.

We also find the connected term, which is not accounted in EquationÂ (9), rises steeply in the nonlinear regime when we directly compute PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} from the simulation (not using Eq.Â 9), corrected for the box-size effect, when we compare with the result of evaluating EquationÂ (9). The importance of the connected term in PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} was already reported in P16 and Alvarez (2016) for the pure dark matter momentum field and for the patchy ionized density field during EoR, respectively. Here, we not only confirm its significance for the free electron momentum field, but find that the connected term in the free electron case accounts for a much higher fraction in PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} than in the pure dark matter case due to enhanced nonlinearity from the baryonic physics. At kâ‰³1â€‹hâ€‹Mpcâˆ’1greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘˜1â„superscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} at zâ‰²1less-than-or-similar-toğ‘§1z\lesssim 1, the connected term constitutes 30%percent3030\% or more of the PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} and this fraction is only a conservative lower limit given that the connected term is not box-size corrected. This is a serious warning against relying on the unconnected term (Eq.Â 9) for computing the kSZ signal. Due to the strong baryonic suppression at low-zğ‘§z, the connected term contribution to the integrated signal is only 6%â€‹(12%)percent6percent126\%\,(12\%) at â„“=3000,(10000)â„“300010000\ell=3000,(10000), but it may be a factor of few larger in larger simulations that are free from the box-size effect.

The resulting kSZ power spectrum is well described by a power-law fit, ğ’Ÿâ„“kSZ,z<6=1.38â€‹[â„“/3000]0.21â€‹Î¼â€‹K2subscriptsuperscriptğ’ŸkSZğ‘§6â„“1.38superscriptdelimited-[]â„“30000.21ğœ‡superscriptğ¾2\mathcal{D}^{{\rm kSZ},z<6}_{\ell}=1.38[\ell/3000]^{0.21}~{}\mu K^{2}, at â„“=3000âˆ’10000â„“300010000\ell=3000-10000. This is impressively close to the result of SRN12 that studied Wesubscriptğ‘Šğ‘’W_{e} in the same context with a different simulation. However, the results from other similar recent kSZ studies are generally higher, varying from 1.71.71.7 to 2.7â€‹Î¼â€‹K22.7ğœ‡superscriptğ¾22.7~{}\mu K^{2} at â„“=3000â„“3000\ell=3000 as listed in Table 1.

Both with this Illustris simulation and the simulation used in SRN12, we expect the kSZ signal to be underestimated. Our work with Illustris is subject to the exaggerated AGN feedback as mentioned above and SRN12 used the L60CSF simulation that is known to over-produce stars. The results of DKS16 (2.1â€‹Î¼â€‹K22.1ğœ‡superscriptğ¾22.1~{}\mu K^{2}) and RVB17 (2.7â€‹Î¼â€‹K22.7ğœ‡superscriptğ¾22.7~{}\mu K^{2}) are however too high to be explained simply by removing the high-kğ‘˜k suppression of the AGN feedback: applying the fe2â€‹beâ€‹02â‰ˆ0.7subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“2ğ‘’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘2ğ‘’00.7f^{2}_{e}b^{2}_{e0}\approx 0.7 factor on the DM model and ignoring the high-kğ‘˜k suppression would yield âˆ¼2.0â€‹Î¼â€‹K2similar-toabsent2.0ğœ‡superscriptğ¾2\sim 2.0~{}\mu K^{2}, which is still lower than those results. Another possibility is that the connected term is much larger in those works. The box-sizes used in RVB17 were 120, 240, and 480Â hâˆ’1â€‹Mpcsuperscriptâ„1Mpch^{-1}~{}\rm{Mpc} and the one used in DKS16 was nearly 900â€‹hâˆ’1â€‹Mpc900superscriptâ„1Mpc900~{}h^{-1}~{}\rm{Mpc}. For those larger box-sizes, the box-size effect on the connected term will be smaller. Also, a weaker AGN feedback may have resulted in the connected term contributing more at low-zğ‘§z than in Illustris.

To clarify these discrepancies in the literature, we need to directly compare Wesubscriptğ‘Šğ‘’W_{e}, fesubscriptğ‘“ğ‘’f_{e}, besubscriptğ‘ğ‘’b_{e}, and the connected term in different Illustris-like high resolution gas simulations with varied feedback scenarios to calibrate the gastrophysical uncertainties in the kSZ predictions. The next round of high resolution large-sky fraction CMB experiments hold great promise for the observations, making such a concerted theoretical and simulational effort imperative. And if we can get to the point of making an accurate subtraction of the post-reionization signal from observations, we can hope to learn about the more gastrophysically complex epoch-of-reionization kSZ signal, and help to constrain EoR physics.

Appendix A CORRECTION FOR THE MISSING POWER IN THE SIMULATION BOX

As shown in EquationÂ (9), PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} is given by a convolution of PÎ´â€‹Î´subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¿ğ›¿P_{\delta\delta} and Pvâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘£ğ‘£P_{vv}. This means PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} at a single wavenumber would receive contributions from PÎ´â€‹Î´subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¿ğ›¿P_{\delta\delta} and Pvâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘£ğ‘£P_{vv} at a range of wavenumbers. Failing to sample density and velocity mode for the whole range of wavenumbers will thus result in underestimation of PqâŸ‚subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}}. In simulations, finite box-size truncate the long wave contributions and can cause this problem (Zhang etÂ al., 2004; Iliev etÂ al., 2007; Park etÂ al., 2013): the integral in EquationÂ (9) is truncated for wavelengths longer than the size of the box, lbox=75â€‹hâˆ’1â€‹Mpcsubscriptğ‘™box75superscriptâ„1Mpcl_{\rm box}=75~{}h^{-1}~{}{\rm Mpc}.

In previous works, the truncation was often set to the fundamental mode kboxâ‰¡2â€‹Ï€/lboxsubscriptğ‘˜box2ğœ‹subscriptğ‘™boxk_{\rm box}\equiv 2\pi/l_{\rm box} of the box and the missing power, PqâŸ‚missingsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒmissingsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP^{\rm missing}_{q_{\perp}}, was then estimated by evaluating the integral for kâ€²<kboxsuperscriptğ‘˜â€²subscriptğ‘˜boxk^{\prime}<k_{\rm box} or |ğ¤âˆ’ğ¤â€²|<kboxğ¤superscriptğ¤â€²subscriptğ‘˜box|\mathbf{k}-\mathbf{k}^{\prime}|<k_{\rm box}, assuming linear PÎ´â€‹Î´subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¿ğ›¿P_{\delta\delta} and Pvâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘£ğ‘£P_{vv} at k<kboxğ‘˜subscriptğ‘˜boxk<k_{\rm box}. We have tested this method for the z=47ğ‘§47z=47 snapshot, where the density and velocity fluctuations should be in the linear regime. If the correction is accurate we are expected to recover EquationÂ (9) evaluated with linear density and velocity power spectra, which is known as the Ostriker-Vishniac spectrum (PqâŸ‚OVsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒOVsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-toP^{\rm OV}_{q_{\perp}}; Efstathiou and Bond, 1987; Vishniac, 1987).
